image.altText: A sketch of Malka Leifer wearing a hair wrap.

items.synopsis: Malka Leifer faces sentencing after she was found guilty of 18 sexual offences in April this year. Follow live.

title.children: Former school principal Malka Leifer to be sentenced for child sexual abuse

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Malka Leifer's victims have waited for years to see her face a sentence for her abuse. 2004-2007: A jury this year found during this time, Leifer carried out several sexual assaults on two victims, Dassi Erlich and Elly Sapper — who were students and then student teachers at Adass Israel School in Melbourne. A jury found Leifer not guilty of raping the third sister, Nicole Meyer, during this period. Late 2007 or early 2008: Dassi Erlich disclosed Leifer's abuse to a social worker, who raised the alarm with a psychiatrist linked to the school community. February 2008: A psychologist contacted the school to raise concerns about Leifer's interactions with students. March 5, 2008: An urgent school board meeting is called and Leifer is confronted about the allegations, which she denies, and told she will be stood down. What exactly occurred next is the subject of a reopened police investigation — ultimately, Leifer left the country at 1:20am the next day for Israel, where she would remain for more than a decade. 2014: After several years, the the sisters provide police statements, which then lead to Victoria Police charging Leifer and beginning an extradition process. 2015: Separate civil legal action is launched by the sisters, with Dassi Erlich awarded more than $1.2 million in damages in the Supreme Court, which found the school was "directly liable" for Leifer's conduct. 2016: An Israeli court orders Leifer be released from home detention due to the severity of her mental illness. The extradition case appears to have ground to a halt. 2017: A community group hires private investigators to tail Leifer. Footage of Leifer running daily errands and shopping raise questions about her claim she is unable to face trial. 2018: After sustained political pressure, including long-running advocacy from former Victorian premier Ted Baillieu, Leifer is re-arrested and the extradition process continues. Late 2020: In her 74th court appearance, Leifer's extradition to Australia is finalised. February 2023: Leifer's trial begins in Victoria's County Court. April 2023: Leifer is found guilty of 18 offences, including six counts of rape. She is found not guilty of nine offences, including all charges relating to Nicole Meyer and some relating to Ms Erlich.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A long journey through the justice system

children.content: Malka Leifer's victims have waited for years to see her face a sentence for her abuse.
A jury this year found during this time, Leifer carried out several sexual assaults on two victims,
Dassi Erlich
and
Elly Sapper
— who were students and then student teachers at
Adass Israel School
in Melbourne. A jury found Leifer not guilty of raping the third sister,
Nicole Meyer
, during this period.
Late 2007 or early 2008:
Dassi Erlich disclosed Leifer's abuse to a social worker, who raised the alarm with a psychiatrist linked to the school community.
February 2008:
A psychologist contacted the school to raise concerns about Leifer's interactions with students.
March 5, 2008:
An urgent school board meeting is called and Leifer is confronted about the allegations, which she denies, and told she will be stood down. What exactly occurred next is the
subject of a reopened police investigation
— ultimately, Leifer left the country at 1:20am the next day for Israel, where she would remain for more than a decade.
After several years,
the the sisters provide police statements, which then lead to Victoria Police charging Leifer and beginning an extradition process.

Separate civil legal action is launched by the sisters, with Dassi Erlich awarded more than $1.2 million in damages in the Supreme Court, which found the school was "directly liable" for Leifer's conduct.
An Israeli court orders Leifer be released from home detention due to the severity of her mental illness. The extradition case appears to have ground to a halt.
A community group hires private investigators to tail Leifer. Footage of Leifer running daily errands and shopping raise questions about her claim she is unable to face trial.
After sustained political pressure, including long-running advocacy from former Victorian premier Ted Baillieu, Leifer is re-arrested and the extradition process continues.
Late 2020:
In her 74th court appearance, Leifer's extradition to Australia is finalised.
February 2023:
Leifer's trial begins in Victoria's County Court.
April 2023:
Leifer
is found guilty of 18 offences, including six counts of rape
. She is found not guilty of nine offences, including all charges relating to Nicole Meyer and some relating to Ms
Erlich.

image.altText: Founder of Wagner private mercenary group Yevgeny Prigozhin in military gear.

items.synopsis: Ten people died after a private jet crashed in Russia's Tver region north of Moscow, Russia's TASS news agency reports.

title.children: Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin killed in plane crash two months after mutiny, Russia's civil aviation authority says

image.altText: Smoke arises from the site of a jet crash near Moscow.

items.synopsis: Warlord Yevgeny Prigozhin was on the passenger list for a private jet that crashed between Moscow and St Petersburg, Russian state media is reporting.

title.children: Prigozhin 'died as a result of the actions of traitors to Russia' says Wagner group, confirming plane crash

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reuters is reporting that the jet model that crashed, with Prigozhin believed to be on board, had a solid safety record, with only one accident recorded in its 20 years of service. Russia's TASS news agency has identified the plane that crashed as a Brazilian Embraer jet known as the Legacy 600, one of the best private jets on the market. The following Embraer jet, registration number RA-02795, is identified by Flightradar24 as belonging to the Wagner group: The flight tracking website showed it dropped off the radar at 6:11pm local time (1:11am AEST). The Legacy 600 first entered service in 2002, according to International Aviation HQ, with almost 300 produced until production ceased in 2020. There is only one recorded accident involving a Legacy 600. In 2006, an Embraer Legacy 600 crashed midair into a Gol 737-800 on its way from the factory in Brazil to the United States. Despite damages to the aircraft, the pilot landed the plane and there were no deaths or injuries. A subsequent inquiry attributed blame to the crew rather than any mechanical failure.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Embraer jet that crashed had a solid safety record

children.content: Reuters is reporting that the jet model that crashed, with Prigozhin believed to be on board, had a solid safety record, with only one accident recorded in its 20 years of service.
Russia's TASS news agency has identified the plane that crashed as a Brazilian Embraer jet known as the Legacy 600, one of the best private jets on the market.
The following Embraer jet, registration number RA-02795, is identified by Flightradar24 as belonging to the Wagner group:

props.alt: A jet with the number RA-02795 sits on a runway

children.content: (JetPhotos via FlightRadar24: Luba Ostrovskaya)
The flight tracking website showed it dropped off the radar at 6:11pm local time (1:11am AEST).
The Legacy 600 first entered service in 2002, according to International Aviation HQ, with almost 300 produced until production ceased in 2020.
There is only one recorded accident involving a Legacy 600. In 2006,
an Embraer Legacy 600 crashed midair into a Gol 737-800 on its way from the factory in Brazil to the United States
. Despite damages to the aircraft, the pilot landed the plane and there were no deaths or injuries. A subsequent inquiry attributed blame to the crew rather than any mechanical failure.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas has recorded an annual profit of $1.7 billion in the last financial year, a dramatic turnaround from a loss of $860 million a year earlier. Its preferred underlying pre-tax profit measure figure is $2.5 billion, and comes after Qantas posted a $1.4 billion profit in its half-yearly results in February. It's the first time since 2019 that Qantas has reported an annual profit, after three years of sustained losses during the COVID-19 pandemic, which grounded the aviation industry. Today’s annual results for the airline are the last from Alan Joyce as CEO before he hands the reins to chief financial officer Vanessa Hudson in November.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas records annual profit of $1.7 billion

Qantas has recorded an annual profit of
$1.7 billion

loss of $860 million
a year earlier.

, and comes after Qantas posted a

profit in its half-yearly results in February.
It's the first time since 2019 that Qantas has reported an annual profit, after three years of sustained losses during the COVID-19 pandemic, which grounded the aviation industry.
Today’s annual results for the airline are the last from Alan Joyce as CEO before he hands the reins to chief financial officer Vanessa Hudson in November.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: North Korea's second attempt to place a spy satellite in orbit has failed but it is vowing to try again in October, state media is reporting. "The flights of the first and second stages of the rocket were normal, but the launch failed due to an error in the emergency blasting system during the third-stage flight," state news agency KCNA says. South Korea's military also says the launch was considered a failure after tracing the vehicle's movement. North Korea's first attempt in May also ended in failure when the new Chollima-1 rocket crashed into the sea. The nuclear-armed country has been seeking to place what would be its first military spy satellite into orbit, saying it eventually plans a fleet of satellites to monitor moves by US and South Korean troops. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: North Korea satellite mission fails, reports local media

children.content: North Korea's second attempt to place a spy satellite in orbit has
failed
but it is vowing to try again in
October
, state media is reporting.

"The flights of the first and second stages of the rocket were normal, but the launch failed due to an error in the emergency blasting system during the third-stage flight," state news agency KCNA says.
South Korea's military also says the launch was considered a failure after tracing the vehicle's movement.
North Korea's first attempt in May also ended in failure when the new Chollima-1 rocket crashed into the sea.

The nuclear-armed country has been seeking to place what would be its first military spy satellite into orbit, saying it eventually plans a fleet of satellites to monitor moves by US and South Korean troops.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: North Korea has launched what appears to be a space rocket, South Korea says, in what would be the North's second such attempt this year after a May launch crashed. The nuclear-armed country has been seeking to place what would be its first military spy satellite into orbit, saying it eventually plans a fleet of satellites to monitor moves by US and South Korean troops. The launch on Thursday has prompted an emergency warning in Japan telling residents of the prefecture of Okinawa to take cover indoors. About 20 minutes following the alert, the Japanese government followed up with a notice that the missile had passed through towards the Pacific Ocean, and it lifted the emergency warning. In a televised press conference, Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary Hirokazu Matsuno said the repeated missile launches were a threat to regional security. "We will strongly protest against North Korea and condemn it in the strongest possible terms," he says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: North Korea launches satellite, prompting emergency Japan alert

props.alt: Kim Jong un, a stout korean man in a black suit

children.content: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un
(Reuters: KCNA)
North Korea has launched what appears to be a space rocket, South Korea says, in what would be the North's second such attempt this year after a
May launch crashed

The nuclear-armed country has been seeking to place what would be its first military spy satellite into orbit, saying it eventually plans a fleet of satellites to monitor moves by US and South Korean troops.
The launch on Thursday has prompted an emergency warning in Japan telling residents of the
prefecture of Okinawa to take cover indoors.
About 20 minutes following the alert, the Japanese government followed up with a notice that the missile had passed through towards the Pacific Ocean, and it lifted the emergency warning.
In a televised press conference, Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary Hirokazu Matsuno said
the repeated missile launches were a threat to regional security.
"We will strongly protest against North Korea and condemn it in the strongest possible terms," he says.

items.synopsis: Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Qantas reveals results, key world economic leaders meet

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, Daniel Ziffer from the ABC's business team with you. The financial results of our national carrier Qantas will be revealed today. There's a lot of criticism of the airline, which in recent years has sacked thousands of workers, lost bags and been accused of running down the brand, to the extent that outgoing CEO Alan Joyce last year said it was "routinely letting customers down". How will shareholders feel later today? And central bankers will meet in the US resort of Jackson Hole. In winter it gets incredible snow and I'd really like to visit, so you're going to be subjected to GIFs like this until I can arrange a "study tour" to preview future meetings. US indicies closed up overnight, the Dow was +0.5% to 34,472.98 points, the broader S & P 500 +1.1% to 4,436.01 points and the tech-laden Nasdaq +1.59% to 13,721.03 points. More to come! (By which I mean skiing GIFs and information).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will Qantas fly or falter?

children.content: Good morning,
Daniel Ziffer from the ABC's business team with you.
The financial results of our national carrier Qantas will be revealed today.
There's a lot of criticism of

the airline, which in recent years has sacked thousands of workers, lost bags and been accused of running down the brand, to the extent that outgoing CEO Alan Joyce last year said it was "routinely letting customers down".
How will shareholders feel later today?

And central bankers will meet in the US resort of Jackson Hole. In winter it gets incredible snow and I'd really like to visit, so you're going to be subjected to GIFs like this until I can arrange a "study tour" to preview future meetings.
US indicies closed up overnight, the Dow was +0.5% to 34,472.98 points, the broader S
P 500 +1.1% to 4,436.01 points and the tech-laden Nasdaq +1.59% to 13,721.03 points.
More to come!
(By which I mean skiing GIFs
and
information).
